A category object SHALL an “id” and a “label” member, and MAY have a “description” member. The value of “id” SHALL be a valid URI string and SHOULD resolve to more detailed information. The value of “label” SHALL be an i18n object of the name of the category and SHOULD be short. If given, the value of “description” SHALL be an i18n object with a textual description of the category.

A parameter object MAY have a member with the name “categoryEncoding” where the value is an object where each key is equal to an “id” value of the “categories” array within the “observedProperty” member of the parameter object. There SHALL be no duplicate keys. The value is either an integer or an array of integers where each integer SHALL be unique within the object.

A parameter object MAY have a member with the name “unit” where the value is an object which SHALL have either or both the members “label” or/and “symbol”, and which MAY have the member “id”. If given, the value of “symbol” SHALL either be a string of the symbolic notation of the unit, or an object with the members “value” and “type” where “value” is the symbolic unit notation and “type” references the unit serialization scheme that is used. “type” SHALL HAVE the value “http://www.opengis.net/def/uom/UCUM/” if UCUM is used, or a custom value as recommended in section “Extensions”. If given, the value of “label” SHALL be an i18n object of the name of the unit and SHOULD be short. If given, the value of “id” SHALL be a string and SHOULD be a common identifier. It is RECOMMENDED to reference a unit serialization scheme to allow automatic unit conversion.
A parameter object SHALL NOT have a “unit” member if the “observedProperty” member has a “categories” member.

clause.title: Requirements Class “Queries” for Position, Area, Cube, Trajectory, Corridor, Items, Locations, and Instances

description.p: For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP GET operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/position.
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP POST operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/position.
The parameter collectionId is each id property in the collections response (JSONPath: $.collections[*].id).
A position GET or POST operation SHALL include a coords query parameter
If the coords query parameter is not specified a HTTP 400 error should be generated
A position GET or POST operation MAY include a z query parameter
A position GET or POST operation SHOULD include a parameter-name query parameter
A position GET or POST operation MAY include a datetime query parameter
A position GET or POST operation SHOULD include a crs query parameter
A position GET or POST operation SHOULD include an f query parameter
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP GET operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/area.
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP POST operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/area.
The parameter collectionId is each id property in the collections response (JSONPath: $.collections[*].id).
An area GET operation SHALL include a coords query parameter
If the coords query parameter is not specified a HTTP 400 error should be generated
An area GET or POST operation MAY include a z query parameter
An area GET or POST operation SHOULD include a parameter-name query parameter
An area GET or POST operation MAY include a datetime query parameter
An area GET or POST operation SHOULD include a crs query parameter
An area GET or POST operation SHOULD include a f query parameter
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP GET operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/cube.
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP POST operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/cube.
The parameter collectionId is each id property in the collections response (JSONPath: $.collections[*].id).
A cube GET or POST operation SHALL include a bbox query parameter
A bbox query parameter SHOULD only consist of four values, any vertical values defined by bbox will be overridden by the values assigned to the z query parameter
If the bbox query parameter is not specified a HTTP 400 error should be generated
A cube GET or POST operation SHALL include a z query parameter
If the z query parameter is not specified a HTTP 400 error should be generated
A cube GET or POST operation SHOULD include a parameter-name query parameter
A cube GET or POST operation MAY include a datetime query parameter
A cube GET or POST operation SHOULD include a crs query parameter
A cube GET or POST operation SHOULD include an f query parameter
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP GET operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/trajectory.
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP POST operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/trajectory.
The parameter collectionId is each id property in the collections response (JSONPath: $.collections[*].id).
A trajectory GET or POST operation SHALL include a coords query parameter
If the coords query parameter is not specified a HTTP 400 error should be generated
A trajectory GET or POST operation MAY include a z query parameter
A trajectory GET or POST operation SHOULD include a parameter-name query parameter
A trajectory GET or POST operation MAY include a datetime query parameter
A trajectory GET or POST operation SHOULD include a crs query parameter
A trajectory GET or POST operation SHOULD include an f query parameter
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP GET operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/corridor.
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP POST operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/corridor.
The parameter collectionId is each id property in the collections response (JSONPath: $.collections[*].id).
A corridor GET operation SHALL include a coords query parameter
If the coords query parameter is not specified, an HTTP 400 error should be generated
A corridor GET operation SHALL include a corridor-width query parameter
If the corridor-width query parameter is not specified, an HTTP 400 error should be generated
A corridor GET operation MUST include a corridor-height query parameter
If the corridor-height query parameter is not specified, an HTTP 400 error should be generated
A corridor GET operation MUST include a width-units query parameter
If the width-units query parameter is not specified, an HTTP 400 error should be generated
If the width-units query parameter value is not one of the supported values a HTTP 400 error should be generated
A corridor GET operation MUST include a height-units query parameter
If the height-units query parameter is not specified, an HTTP 400 error should be generated
If the height-units query parameter value is not one of the supported values a HTTP 400 error should be generated
A corridor GET or POST operation MAY include a z query parameter
A corridor GET or POST operation SHOULD include a parameter-name query parameter
A corridor GET or POST operation MAY include a datetime query parameter
A corridor GET or POST operation SHOULD include a crs query parameter
A corridor GET or POST operation SHOULD include a f query parameter
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP GET operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/radius.
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP POST operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/radius.
The parameter collectionId is each id property in the collections response (JSONPath: $.collections[*].id).
A radius GET or POST operation SHALL include a coords query parameter
If the coords query parameter is not specified, an HTTP 400 error should be generated
A radius GET or POST operation SHALL include a within query parameter
If the within query parameter is not specified, an HTTP 400 error should be generated
A radius GET or POST operation MUST include a within-units query parameter
If the within-units query parameter is not specified, an HTTP 400 error should be generated
A radius GET or POST operation MAY include a z query parameter
A radius GET or POST operation SHOULD include a parameter-name query parameter
A radius GET or POST operation MAY include a datetime query parameter
A radius GET or POST operation SHOULD include a crs query parameter
A radius GET or POST operation SHOULD include an f query parameter
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP GET operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/items.
The parameter collectionId is each id property in the feature collections response (JSONPath: $.collections[*].id).
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP GET operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/locations.
For every collection identified in the collections response (path /collections), the server MAY support the HTTP POST operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/locations.
The parameter collectionId is each id property in the feature collections response (JSONPath: $.collections[*].id).
If a locationId is not specified a list of valid locationId’s SHALL be returned with a description of their geospatial extent.
A locations GET or POST operation SHOULD include a parameter-name query parameter
A locations GET or POST operation MAY include a datetime query parameter
A locations GET or POST operation SHOULD include a crs query parameter
A locations GET or POST operation SHOULD include an f query parameter
The API MAY support the HTTP GET operation at the path /collections/{collection_id}/instances.
A successful execution of the operation SHALL be reported as a response with a HTTP status code 200.
The API SHALL support the HTTP GET operation at the path /collections/{collectionId}/instances/{instanceId}.
The parameter collectionId is each id property in the resource collections response (JSONPath: $.collections[*].id) and instanceId is each id property of instances of the chosen collection.
A successful execution of the operation SHALL be reported as a response with a HTTP status code 200.
The content of that response SHALL be based upon the JSON schema instances.yaml.

The content of that response SHALL be consistent with the content for this resource collection in the /collections response. That is, the values for id, title, description and extent SHALL be identical.
The operation SHALL support a parameter bbox with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: bbox in: query required: false schema: oneOf: - items: minItems: 4 maxItems: 4 type: number type: array - items: minItems: 6 maxItems: 6 type: number type: array style: form explode: false

description.p: Only features that have a spatial geometry that intersects the bounding box SHALL be part of the result set, if the bbox parameter is provided.
If a feature has multiple spatial geometry properties, it is the decision of the server whether only a single spatial geometry property is used to determine the extent or all relevant geometries.
The bbox parameter SHALL match all features in the collection that are not associated with a spatial geometry, too.
The bounding box is provided as four or six numbers, depending on whether the coordinate reference system includes a vertical axis (height or depth):

li.p: Lower left corner, coordinate axis 1
Lower left corner, coordinate axis 2
Minimum value, coordinate axis 3 (optional)
Upper right corner, coordinate axis 1
Upper right corner, coordinate axis 2
Maximum value, coordinate axis 3 (optional)

description.p: The bounding box SHALL consist of four or six numbers, depending on whether the coordinate reference system includes a vertical axis (height or depth) and the coordinate reference system of the values SHALL be interpreted as the coordinate reference system that is specified in a parameter crs.

If the crs query parameter is not defined, the bounding box SHALL consist of four or six numbers, depending on whether the coordinate reference system includes a vertical axis (height or depth) and the coordinate reference system of the values SHALL be interpreted as the default coordinate reference system specified for the query type.

If the crs query parameter is not defined and a default crs is not defined for the query, the bounding box SHALL consist of four numbers and the coordinate reference system of the values SHALL be in the CRS defined by the spatial element of the extent section in the collection response.
The coordinate values SHALL be within the extent specified for the coordinate reference system.

Each geometry based resource (Position, Radius, Area, Trajectory, Corridor) collection operation SHALL support a parameter coords with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: coords in: query required: true schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: The coords string value will be a Well Known Text representation of geometry as defined in Simple Feature Access — Part 1: Common Architecture. The representation type will depend on the queryType of the API
Only those resources that are representative of the requested geometry that is defined by the coords parameter SHALL be part of the result set.
The coordinates SHALL consist of a Well Known Text (WKT) POINT or (if supported by the collection) MULTIPOINT geometry string.
If an unsupported Well Known Text (WKT) geometry is requested a 400 error SHOULD be returned.
The coordinate reference system of the values SHALL be interpreted as WGS84 longitude/latitude

figure.pre: WKT: GEOGCS["WGS 84", DATUM["WGS_1984", SPHEROID["WGS 84", 6378137, 298.257223563, AUTHORITY["EPSG", "7030"]], AUTHORITY["EPSG", "6326"]], PRIMEM["Greenwich", 0 , AUTHORITY["EPSG", "8901"]], UNIT["degree", 0.01745329251994328, AUTHORITY["EPSG", "9122"]], AUTHORITY["EPSG", "4326"]]

description.p: unless a different coordinate reference system is specified in a parameter crs.
Only those resources that are representative of the requested geometry that is defined by the coords parameter SHALL be part of the result set.
The coordinates SHALL consist of a Well Known Text (WKT) POLYGON or (if supported by the collection) MULTIPOLYGON geometry string.
If an unsupported Well Known Text (WKT) geometry is requested a 400 error SHOULD be returned.
The coordinate reference system of the values SHALL be interpreted as WGS84 longitude/latitude

figure.pre: WKT: GEOGCS["WGS 84", DATUM["WGS_1984", SPHEROID["WGS 84", 6378137, 298.257223563, AUTHORITY["EPSG", "7030"]], AUTHORITY["EPSG", "6326"]], PRIMEM["Greenwich", 0 , AUTHORITY["EPSG", "8901"]], UNIT["degree", 0.01745329251994328, AUTHORITY["EPSG", "9122"]], AUTHORITY["EPSG", "4326"]]

description.p: unless a different coordinate reference system is specified in a parameter crs.
Only those resources that are representative of the requested geometry that is defined by the coords parameter SHALL be part of the result set.
The coordinates SHALL consist of a Well Known Text (WKT) LINESTRING or (if supported by the collection) MULTILINESTRING geometry string.
If an unsupported Well Known Text (WKT) geometry is requested a 400 error SHOULD be returned.
The coordinate reference system of the values SHALL be interpreted as WGS84 longitude/latitude

figure.pre: WKT: GEOGCS["WGS 84", DATUM["WGS_1984", SPHEROID["WGS 84", 6378137, 298.257223563, AUTHORITY["EPSG", "7030"]], AUTHORITY["EPSG", "6326"]], PRIMEM["Greenwich", 0 , AUTHORITY["EPSG", "8901"]], UNIT["degree", 0.01745329251994328, AUTHORITY["EPSG", "9122"]], AUTHORITY["EPSG", "4326"]]

description.p: unless a different coordinate reference system is specified in a parameter crs.
The datetime parameter SHALL have the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: datetime in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: If the datetime parameter is provided, only resources that have a temporal geometry that intersects the temporal information in the datetime parameter SHALL be part of the result set.
If a resource has multiple temporal properties, the API implementor decides whether only a single temporal property is used to determine the extent or all relevant temporal properties.
The datetime parameter SHALL match all resources in the collection that are not associated with a temporal geometry.
The temporal information is either a date-time or a time interval. The parameter value SHALL conform to the following syntax (using ABNF):
description.sourcecode: interval-closed = date-time "/" date-time interval-open-start = "../" date-time interval-open-end = date-time "/.." interval = interval-closed / interval-open-start / interval-open-end datetime = date-time / interval

description.p: The syntax of date-time is specified by RFC 3339, 5.6.
Open ranges in time intervals at the start or end SHALL be supported using a double-dot (..).
Each resource collection operation SHALL support a parameter parameter-name with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: parameter-name in: query required: false explode: false schema: minItems: 1 type: array items: type: string

description.p: If the parameter-name parameter is provided, only those parameters named SHALL be returned. If the parameter-name parameter is not specified all parameters in the collection SHALL be returned.
The parameter-name parameter SHALL consist of a comma delimited string value based on an enumerated list of options listed in the collections metadata.
Each resource collection operation SHALL support a parameter crs with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: crs in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: If the crs parameter is provided, the returned information should be reprojected (if required) to the defined coordinate system. If the crs parameter is not specified the data will be returned in its native projection.
The crs parameter SHALL consist of an identifier selected from the enumerated list of valid values supplied in the collections metadata.
If an unsupported crs value is requested a 400 error message SHOULD be returned.
Each resource collection operation SHALL support a parameter f with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: f in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: If the f parameter is provided, the returned information should be transformed to the defined data format.
The f parameter SHALL consist of a string value based on an enumerated list of available options provided in the collections metadata.

If f value is not defined the returned data should be in the default format specified by the default_output_format attribute of the collections metadata response. If a default_output_format attribute is not specified, the data return SHOULD be in the native format of the source datastore.
If an unsupported f value is requested a 400 error message should be returned.
Each resource collection operation MAY support a parameter z with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: z in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

clause.title: Requirement /req/edr/z-response Parameter z response

description.p: If the z parameter is provided, only resources that have a vertical geometry that intersects the vertical information in the z parameter SHALL be part of the result set.
The z can be defined as a height range by specifying a min-level and max-level separated by a forward slash ”/“
A list of z can be defined be specifying a comma delimited list of values level1, level2, level3 etc
An Arithmetic sequence using Recurring height intervals can be specified by Rnumber of intervals/min height/height interval
If the z parameter is not provided, the server SHOULD return data at all available vertical levels

clause.sourcecode: single-level = level interval-closed = min-level "/" max-level level-list = level1 "," level2 "," level3 repeating-interval = "R"number of intervals "/" min-level "/" height to increment by

Single level at level 850 z=850
All data between levels 100 and 550 z=100/550
Data at levels 10,80,100 z=10,80,200
Data at 20 levels at 50 unit intervals starting a level 100 z=R20/100/50

description.p: Each resource collection operation MAY support a parameter within with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
If the instance metadata does not provide within-units values the API SHALL NOT support within queries:
description.sourcecode: name: within in: query required: true schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: If the within parameter is provided, all selected information within the specified radius SHALL be part of the result set.
If a within-units parameter is not provided, a 400 error WILL be returned.
Each resource collection operation MAY support a parameter within-units with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
A within-units value SHALL be one of the values defined in the instance metadata:
description.sourcecode: name: within-units in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: The within-units parameter defines the distance units of the within query parameter value.
Each resource collection operation MAY support a parameter resolution-x with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: resolution-x in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: If the resolution-x parameter is provided, it denotes the number of positions to retrieve data for, across the width of the corridor path, including its minimum and maximum width coordinates.
A resolution-x value of 0 SHALL return all available data at the stored resolution between (and including) the minimum and maximum coordinates of the defined corridor.
If resolution-x is not specified, the API SHOULD return all available data at a resolution determined by the server, including the minimum and maximum coordinates of the defined corridor.
description.sourcecode: resolution-x = number of intervals + 1

clause.title: Requirement /req/edr/cube-z-response Parameter z response for cube queries

description.p: If the z parameter is provided, only resources that have a vertical geometry that intersects the vertical information in the z parameter SHALL be part of the result set.
The z can be defined as a height range by specifying a min-level and max-level separated by a forward slash ”/“
A list of z can be defined by specifying a comma delimited list of values level1, level2, level3 etc
An Arithmetic sequence using Recurring height intervals can be specified by Rnumber of intervals/min height/height interval
If the z parameter is not provided, the server SHOULD return data at all available vertical levels
Each resource collection operation MAY support a parameter resolution-y with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: resolution-y in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: If the resolution-y parameter is provided, denotes the number of intervals to retrieve data for along the path between the minimum and maximum y coordinates
The total number of intervals includes the values for the minimum and maximum coordinates
A resolution-y value of 0 SHALL return all available data at the native y resolution between the minimum and maximum coordinates
IF resolution-y is not specified, data should be returned for just the locations specified in the requested coordinates (ONLY IF interpolation is supported by the API)
description.sourcecode: resolution-y = number of intervals

description.p: Each resource collection operation MAY support a parameter resolution-z with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: resolution-z in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: If the resolution-z parameter is provided, it denotes the number of positions to retrieve data for, over the depth of the corridor path including its minimum and maximum width coordinates.
A resolution-z value of 0 SHALL return all available data at the stored vertical resolution between (and including) the minimum and maximum coordinates of the defined corridor.
If resolution-z is not specified the API SHOULD return all available data at a resolution determined by the server, including the minimum and maximum coordinates of the defined corridor.
description.sourcecode: resolution-z = number of intervals + 1

description.p: Each resource collection operation SHALL support a parameter corridor-height with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: corridor-height in: query required: true schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: If the corridor-height parameter is defined the result set SHALL contain values derived from the chosen interpolation algorithm at the number of specified intervals.
description.sourcecode: corridor-height = height

description.p: The height of the corridor parameter is the total height of the required corridor.
The coordinates of the coords parameter define the center point of the corridor.
If an unsupported units value is requested, an HTTP 400 error should be returned.
Each corridor resource collection operation SHALL support a parameter height-units with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: height-units in: query required: true schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: If the height-units parameter is defined the result set SHALL contain values derived based on the chosen units.
description.sourcecode: height-units = units

description.p: If an unsupported units value is requested, an HTTP 400 error should be returned.
Each resource collection operation SHALL support a parameter corridor-width with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: corridor-width in: query required: true schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: The corridor-width information SHALL be the total width of the required corridor.
The supported corridor-width width units SHALL be supplied by the query metadata information.
description.sourcecode: corridor-width = width

description.p: If the width value SHALL be the total width of the corridor.
The coordinates of the coords parameter SHALL define the center point of the corridor.
If an unsupported units value is requested, an HTTP 400 error SHOULD be returned.
Each corridor resource collection operation SHALL support a parameter width-units with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: name: width-units in: query required: true schema: type: string style: form explode: false

description.p: If the width-units parameter is defined the result set SHALL contain values derived based on the chosen units.
description.sourcecode: width-units = units

description.p: If an unsupported units value is requested a 400 error should be returned.
Each resource collection operation MAY support custom parameters with the following characteristics (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
description.sourcecode: in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

clause.title: Requirement /req/edr/custom-dimension-response Custom Parameter response

description.p: If a custom parameter is provided, only resources that have values that are valid for the range defined in the custom query parameter SHALL be part of the result set.
The custom query parameter can be defined as a value range by specifying a min-value and max-value separated by a forward slash ”/“
A list of query values can be defined be specifying a comma delimited list of values value1, value2, value3 etc
An Arithmetic sequence using Recurring value intervals can be specified by Rnumber of intervals/min value/value interval
If a custom dimension is defined in the collections response but not included in the query request all valid values should be returned with no subsetting by the custom dimension.

clause.sourcecode: single-value = value interval-closed = min-value "/" max-value value-list = value1 "," value2 "," value3 repeating-interval = "R"number of intervals "/" min-value "/" value to increment by

The server SHALL implement all capabilities specified in the OpenAPI definition.
The content of the response of the HTTP GET operation at the landing page SHALL include the following links to the API definition:

li.p: relation type service-desc and content type application/vnd.oai.openapi+json;version=3.0,
relation type service-doc and content type text/html.

description.p: The JSON representation SHALL conform to the OpenAPI Specification, version 3.0.
The OpenAPI definition SHALL specify for each operation all HTTP Status Codes and Response Objects that the API uses in responses.
This includes the successful execution of an operation as well as all error situations that originate from the server.
For error situations that originate from an API server, the API definition SHALL cover all applicable HTTP Status Codes.
For cases, where the operations of the API are access-controlled, the security scheme(s) and requirements SHALL be documented in the OpenAPI definition.

clause.title: Introduction
clause.p: The Abstract Test Suite (ATS) is a compendium of test assertions applicable to implementations of the EDR API. An ATS provides a basis for developing an Executable Test Suite to verify that the implementation under test conforms to all the relevant functional specifications.
The abstract test cases (assertions) are organized into test groups that correspond to distinct conformance test classes defined in the EDR API specification.

OGC APIs are not Web Services in the traditional sense. Rather, they define the behavior and content of a set of Resources exposed through a Web Application Programing Interface (Web API). Therefore, an API may expose resources in addition to those defined by the standard. A test engine shall be able to traverse the API, identify and validate test points, and ignore resource paths which are not to be tested.

component.p: Validate that the resource paths advertised through the API conform with HTTP 1.1 and, where appropriate, TLS.
All compliance tests shall be configured to use the HTTP 1.1 protocol exclusively.
For APIs which support HTTPS, all compliance tests shall be configured to use HTTP over TLS (RFC 2818) with their HTTP 1.1 protocol.

clause.title: Landing Page {root}/

component.p: Validate that a landing page can be retrieved from the expected location.
Issue an HTTP GET request to the URL {root}/
Validate that a document was returned with a status code 200
Validate the contents of the returned document using test /conf/core/root-success.
Validate that the landing page complies with the required structure and contents.
Validate the landing page for all supported media types using the resources and tests identified in

li.p: Validate that the landing page includes a “service-desc” and/or “service-doc” link to an API Definition
Validate that the landing page includes a “conformance” link to the conformance class declaration

component.sourcecode: name: z in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

component.p: Validate that the vertical level query parameters are processed correctly.
Verify that only resources that have a vertical geometry that intersects the vertical information in the z parameter were included in the result set
Validate that the vertical level parameter complies with the syntax described in /req/edr/z-response.
Validate that the datetime query parameters are constructed correctly.
Verify that the datetime query parameter complies with the following definition (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
component.sourcecode: name: datetime in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

component.p: Validate that the datetime query parameters are processed correctly.
Verify that only resources that have a temporal geometry that intersects the temporal information in the datetime parameter were included in the result set.
Verify that all resources in the collection that are not associated with a temporal geometry are included in the result set.
Validate that the datetime parameter complies with the syntax described in /req/core/datetime-response.
Validate that the parameter-name query parameters are constructed correctly.
Verify that the parameter-name query parameter complies with the following definition (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
component.sourcecode: name: parameter-name in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

component.p: Validate that the parameter-name query parameters are processed correctly.
Verify that only resources for the requested parameters were included in the result set
Validate that the parameter-name parameter complies with the syntax described in /req/edr/parameter-name-response.
Validate that the crs query parameters are constructed correctly.
Verify that the crs query parameter complies with the following definition (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
component.sourcecode: name: crs in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

component.p: Validate that the crs query parameters are processed correctly.
Verify that the geometry of the resources returned are valid for the requested coordinate reference system
Verify that all crs values defined in the collections metadata are supported by the collection
Verify that all crs values not defined in the collections metadata will generate a HTTP 400 error
Validate that the crs parameter complies with the syntax described in /req/edr/REQ_rc-crs-response.
Validate that the f query parameter is constructed correctly.
Verify that the f query parameter complies with the following definition (using an OpenAPI Specification 3.0 fragment):
component.sourcecode: name: f in: query required: false schema: type: string style: form explode: false

component.p: Validate that the f query parameters are processed correctly.
Verify that the response is returned in the requested data format
Verify that all output format values defined in the collections metadata are supported by the collection
Validate that the f parameter complies with the syntax described in /req/edr/REQ_rc-f-response.

annex.title: Collection Response Metadata (Informative)
annex.p: This Annex contains a more-easily human-readable view of the content in the OpenAPI definitions.
The collection response structure provides the details which describe the information available and the query capabilities supported by the collections served by the API.

clause.title: EDR Collection Object Structure
clause.p: Collection objects describe both collections and instances of a collection.

tr.td: Unique identifier string for the collection, used as the value for the collection_id path parameter in all queries on the collection
A short text label for the collection
A text description of the information provided by the collection
Array of words and phrases that define the information that the collection provides
Object describing the spatio-temporal extent of the information provided by the collection
Array of coordinate reference system names, which define the output coordinate systems supported by the collection
Array of data format names, which define the data formats to which information in the collection can be output
Describes the data values available in the collection

clause.title: Link Object
clause.p: OGC Web API Standards use RFC 8288 (Web Linking) to express relationships between resources. The “link” elements provide a convention for associating resources related to the collection.

tr.td: Relation type of the URL. A list of valid relation types can be found at
Type of information being returned by the URL
Attribute used to specify the language and geographical targeting of information accessed by the URL. Can be defined by using a value from either languages ISO 639-1 or countries ISO 3166-1
A short text label to describe the URL
If True the URL includes templated values for mandatory Query parameters
Object providing custom information relevant to the link

clause.title: Variables Object
clause.p: The variables object provides fields to describe information that only applies to the owning link.

tr.td: A short text label for the query
One of: position, radius, area, cube, trajectory, corridor, items, locations, instances
An example of valid coords query parameter values
A list of the valid within units for radius queries
A list of the valid width units
A list of the valid height units
A list of output formats supported by the query, if this field exists it overrides the output formats definition supplied at a collection level.
Specifies the default output format for the query
A list of coordinate reference systems supported by the query, if this field exists it overrides the crs values defined at a collection level.

clause.title: CRS Details Object
clause.p: A crs details object describes a coordinate system.

tr.td: Name of the coordinate reference system, used as the value in the crs query parameter to define the required output coordinate reference system
Well Known Text description of the coordinate reference system

clause.p: A simple link example is shown below.
A more complex link example supporting a templated href with a mandatory coords parameter is shown below.

clause.title: Extent Object
clause.p: The extent object describes the spatio-temporal area covered by the information available in the collection.

tr.td: Object defining the spatial extent of the information in the collection
Object defining the temporal extent of the information in the collection
Object defining the vertical extent of the information in the collection

clause.title: Spatial Object
clause.p: The spatial object describes the spatial area covered by the information available in the collection.

td.p: A bounding box is provided as four numbers:

li.p: Lower left corner, coordinate axis 1
Lower left corner, coordinate axis 2
Upper right corner, coordinate axis 1
Upper right corner, coordinate axis 2

tr.td: This can either be a Well Known Text definition of the CRS or follow a convention of where the token {authority} is a placeholder for a code the designates to authority responsible for the definition of this CRS. Typical values include “EPSG” and “OGC”. The token {version} is a placeholder for the specific version of the coordinate reference system definition or 0 for the latest version or if the version is unknown. The token {code} is a placeholder for the authority’s code for the CRS.

clause.title: Temporal Object
clause.p: The temporal object describes the time period covered by the information available in the collection.

tr.td: An array of ISO 8601 Date Array, each ISO 8601 Date Array should contain two values first being the minimum date time and second the maximum date time for information in the collection (see )

An array of ISO 8601 datestrings which details the time intervals available in the collection, each member of the array can either be a single time, an ISO 8601 time interval or an ISO 8601 time duration (see )
This defaults to Gregorian, but other temporal systems can be supported following the conventions defined by the Well Known Text standard.

clause.title: Vertical Object
clause.p: The vertical object describes the vertical extent of information available in the collection.

tr.td: Array of level values array, each Level value Array should contain two values first being the minimum vertical level and second the maximum vertical level for information in the collection
Array of height values supported by the collection.
Follows the conventions defined by the Well Known Text standard.

clause.p: A simple extent object example for collection with no vertical or temporal dimensions is shown below.
clause.sourcecode: "extent": { "spatial": { "bbox": [[1393.0196, 13494.9764, 671196.3657, 1230275.0454]], "crs": "PROJCS[\"OSGB 1936 / British National Grid\", GEOGCS[\"OSGB 1936\",DATUM[\"OSGB_1936\", SPHEROID[\"Airy 1830\",6377563.396,299.3249646, AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"7001\"]],AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"6277\"]], PRIMEM[\"Greenwich\",0,AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"8901\"]], UNIT[\"degree\",0.01745329251994328, AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"9122\"]],AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"4277\"]], UNIT[\"metre\",1,AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"9001\"]], PROJECTION[\"Transverse_Mercator\"], PARAMETER[\"latitude_of_origin\",49],PARAMETER[\"central_meridian\",-2], PARAMETER[\"scale_factor\",0.9996012717],PARAMETER[\"false_easting\",400000], PARAMETER[\"false_northing\",-100000],AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"27700\"], AXIS[\"Easting\",EAST],AXIS[\"Northing\",NORTH]]" } }
clause.p: Below is a more complex extent object example for a collection with vertical and temporal dimensions.
clause.sourcecode: "extent": { "spatial": { "bbox": [[-180.0,-90.0,180.0,90.0]], "crs": "GEOGCS[\"WGS 84\",DATUM[\"WGS_1984\", SPHEROID[\"WGS 84\",6378137,298.257223563, AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"7030\"]],AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"6326\"]], PRIMEM[\"Greenwich\",0,AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"8901\"]], UNIT[\"degree\",0.01745329251994328, AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"9122\"]],AUTHORITY[\"EPSG\",\"4326\"]]" }, "temporal": { "interval": [["2021-04-22T00:00:00Z","2021-05-03T12:00:00Z"]], "values": ["R82/2021-04-22T00:00:00Z/PT3H", "R2/2021-05-02T12:00:00Z/PT12H"], "trs": "TIMECRS[\"DateTime\",TDATUM[\"Gregorian Calendar\"], CS[TemporalDateTime,1],AXIS[\"Time (T)\",future]]" }, "vertical": { "interval": [["1829.0","3658.0"]], "values": ["1829.0","2743.0","3658.0"], "vrs": "VERT_CS['MSL height', VERT_DATUM['Mean Sea Level',2005, AUTHORITY['EPSG','5100']], UNIT['metre',1,AUTHORITY['EPSG','9001']], AXIS['Up',UP],AUTHORITY['EPSG','5714']]" } }

clause.title: Data Queries Object
clause.p: The data queries object provides the extra metadata required for the queries supported by the collection.

clause.title: EDR Query Object
clause.p: The EDR query object provides the metadata for the specified query type.

tr.td: Array of height values supported by the collection.

clause.p: A data query object example for a collection that supports Position and Radius queries is shown below.

clause.title: Parameter Names Object
clause.p: The parameter-names object provides information about the data parameters supported by the collection. As a set of key-value pairs, where the key is the name of the parameter and the value is a Parameter object i.e. as a Dictionary (Python) or HashMap(Java).

tr.td: A short text label for the parameter
The data type of the parameter values [integer, float, string]
A description of the units of the parameter values
A formal definition of the parameter
Information on the spatio-temporal extent of the parameter values (if different from other parameters in the collection)
Information on how the value was derived

clause.title: Unit Object
clause.p: The unit object provides the information to describe the units of measure of the parameter values.

tr.td: Information to describe the symbols used to represent the unit

clause.title: Symbol Object
clause.p: The symbol object provides the information to describe the symbols which represent the unit of a value.

tr.td: A text description of the symbol
A Unicode representation for the symbol
A URI to a registry entry providing more detailed information about the unit (i.e. QUDT is one example of a registry that provide links for many common units)

clause.title: Observed Property Object
clause.p: The observedProperty object provides the metadata for the specified query type.

tr.td: URI linking to an external registry which contains the definitive definition of the observed property
A short text label for the property
A description of the observed property

clause.title: Measurement Type object
clause.p: The measurementType object provides basic information about how the parameter is calculated and over what time period.

tr.td: Calculation method e.g. Mean, Sum, Max, etc.

td.p: Duration of calculation. For time durations, this follows the ISO 8601 Duration standard.

li.p: A negative sign before a duration value (i.e. -PT10M) infers that the time start starts at the specified duration before the time value assigned to the parameter value.

So if the measurement had a time value of 2020-04-05T14:30Z and a measurementType duration of -PT10M the value is representative of the period 2020-04-05T14:20Z/2020-04-05T14:30Z; if the measurement had a time value of 2020-04-05T14:30Z and a measurementType duration of PT10M the value is representative of the period 2020-04-05T14:30Z/2020-04-05T14:40Z

clause.p: A Parameter names example is shown below.

clause.title: Introduction
clause.p: This Annex outlines the relationships, in terms of underlying conceptual models, overlaps, gaps, and target use cases and technologies, with other OGC Standards.

clause.title: Relationship between OGC API-EDR and OGC API-Features
clause.p: The EDR API is completely compatible with OGC API — Features — Part 1: Core (OGC 17-069r3), in that it supports Collections and Items. It extends the Collection functionality by allowing ‘Instances’, a form of ‘collection of collections’. The EDR API also supports the retrieval of spatiotemporal data by named location as well as coordinates.

clause.title: Relationships between OGC API-EDR and Moving Features standards
clause.p: There are four OGC Moving Features standards: conceptual model with XML encoding (OGC 18-075), access (OGC 16-120r3), CSV encoding (OGC 14-084r2), and JSON encoding (OGC 19-045r3). The Moving Features Standards are concerned with things that move along a trajectory, and simultaneously change their orientation through rigid body rotation. The concepts are defined in Unified Modeling Language (UML) and encoded in GML. The EDR API does not have the concept of orientation, or foliation or prisms. EDR API is OpenAPI defined, over HTTP(S), and not defined in UML.

Moving Features and EDR API do share a common conceptual definition, from ISO, of a Trajectory, but the Moving Features Standards encode trajectories in GML, CSV and Moving Features JSON, whereas the EDR API encodes trajectories in WKT. The Moving Features Standards support relationships between trajectories and other features, including other trajectories, the EDR API does not. Moving Features also explicitly supports concepts such as velocity, acceleration and distance along a trajectory, whereas the EDR API does not.

The Moving Features Standards consider trajectories as a primary resource to be queried, manipulated and processed, whereas in the EDR API, a trajectory is simply a query sampling pattern, encoded in WKT and ISO 8601 Date Time Format, into a spatiotemporal data resource.

clause.title: Relationships between OGC API-EDR and Web Coverage Service and Coverage Implementation Schema
clause.p: The primary messaging mechanism of the EDR API is JSON, including CoverageJSON, over HTTP(S). Implementations of the EDR API are described using the OpenAPI V3.0 specification. The target users are web-developers and end-users who are not geospatial experts. The target data resources are any dataset described as spatiotemporal, accessible by coordinates.

The EDR API is consistent with the Web Coverage Service (WCS) and Coverage Implementation Schema (CIS) standards but does not require the end user or developer to use the terms Domain and RangeSet. The EDR API can also be used to generate a single query against a collection of coverages, providing the data coordinate reference systems are consistent. The EDR API can support any of the WCS and CIS output formats if required. At the time of publication of version 1.0.0 of the EDR API, at least one EDR API implementation had been created by building on top of a WCS/CIS implementation.
The EDR API, with only a single form of spatiotemporal query, allows the retrieval of data from other data stores adhering to data models that are not coverages, such as features or observations.

clause.title: Relationship between OGC API-EDR and the OGC MetOcean Application profile of Web Coverage Service (WCS) 2.1
clause.p: The OGC API-EDR standard was developed out of the experiences of creating Part 0, Part 1 and Part 2 of the WCS 2.1 Met Ocean Application Profile, ostensibly for similar use cases, but for differing technology bases.

The primary messaging mechanism of the EDR API is JSON, including CoverageJSON, over HTTP(S). Implementations of the EDR API are described using the OpenAPI V3.0 specification. The target users are web-developers and end-users who are not geospatial experts. The target data resources are any data described as spatiotemporal, accessible by coordinates, not just meteorological or oceanographic.

In contrast, the Met Ocean Application Profile of WCS 2.1 is designed primarily to support XML-encoded messaging, in particular, for GetCapabilities and GetCoverage requests. Responses returning coverages are modelled according to the CIS, which can be XML, JSON or JSON-LD. Developers and end-users are expected to be familiar with the geospatial terminology of coverages, and use the Profile with predominantly meteorological or oceanographic data.

The EDR API and the Met Ocean WCS Profile therefore support different use cases. Developers that are interested in extending their OWS or WCS solutions to support the Met Ocean domain are advised to use the Met Ocean Application Profile of WCS. Developers that are implementing Web APIs that make use of the OpenAPI specification are advised to use the EDR API.

clause.title: Relationships between OGC API-EDR, SOS and SensorThings API
clause.p: Both the OGC Sensor Observation Service (SOS) and the OGC SensorThings API enable access to observations made by sensors and transmitted over networks. As stated in Part 1 of the SensorThings API Standard “The main difference between the SensorThings API and the OGC SOS and Sensor Planning Service (SPS) is that the SensorThings API is designed specifically for the resource-constrained IoT devices and the Web developer community” (OGC 15-078r6).

Therefore, although the SensorThings API had overlaps with SOS within Web use cases, the OGC Membership acknowledged that there were some use cases within the IoT that could not be efficiently nor effectively addressed by the SOS. The same is true for the relationship between the EDR API and the SensorThings API.

SensorThings API follows OData’s specification for requesting entities. That means the entity control information, resource path usages, query options, the relevant JSON encodings, and batch-processing request follow OData 4.0. In contrast, the EDR API makes use of the OpenAPI V3.0 specification for describing resource paths, query options, JSON schema, and other aspects.

Further, the EDR API allows for retrieval of coverage data and HTML responses – both of which are not supported by the SensorThings API. Therefore, developers that are interested in IoT devices and OData, and do not have a need for HTML previews of content are advised to make use of the SensorThings API instead. Similarly, developers that are interested in XML-encoded observations and sensor model descriptions are advised to make use of the SOS.

Similarly, an EDR or SensorThings API interface could be deployed on the same data set, so that users and developers that do not need the full details of observational, feature or coverage conceptual models and associated metadata could use the EDR API to hide the extra complexity, while users that do need all the details can use the SensorThings API to retrieve those.

verbal-definition.p: A compendium of test assertions applicable to implementations of a standard. An ATS provides a basis for developing an Executable Test Suite to verify that the implementation under test conforms to all the relevant functional specifications.
body of resources that belong or are used together. An aggregate, set, or group of related resources. (OGC 20-024)
set of related tests, all within a single conformance test class (OGC 08-131r3)

termnote.p: When no ambiguity is possible, the word test may be omitted. i.e. conformance test module is the same as conformance module. Conformance modules may be nested in a hierarchical way.

verbal-definition.p: set of conformance test modules that shall be applied to receive a single certificate of conformance (OGC 08-131r3)

termnote.p: When no ambiguity is possible, the word test may be left out, so conformance test class maybe called a conformance class.

verbal-definition.p: collection of data, published or curated by a single agent, and available for access or download in one or more formats (DCAT)
represents an accessible form of a dataset (DCAT)

termnote.p: EXAMPLE: a downloadable file, an RSS feed or a web service that provides the data.

verbal-definition.p: A set of code (e.g. Java and Compliance Test Language) that provides runtime tests for the assertions defined by the ATS. Test data required to do the tests are part of the ETS (OGC 08-134)

expression in the content of a document conveying that among several possibilities one is recommended as particularly suitable, without mentioning or excluding others, or that a certain course of action is preferred but not necessarily required, or that (in the negative form) a certain possibility or course of action is deprecated but not prohibited (OGC 08-131r3)
expression in the content of a document conveying criteria to be fulfilled if compliance with the document is to be claimed and from which no deviation is permitted (OGC 08-131r3)
aggregate of all requirement modules that shall all be satisfied to satisfy a conformance test class (OGC 08-131r3)
aggregate of requirements and recommendations of a specification against a single standardization target type (OGC 08-131r3)
resources usually considered as Geospatial Data. (OGC 19-072)
entity to which some requirements of a standard apply (OGC 08-131r3)

termnote.p: The standardization target is the entity which may receive a certificate of conformance for a requirements class.

verbal-definition.p: API using an architectural style that is founded on the technologies of the Web. (W3C Data on the Web Best Practices)

bibitem.title: OpenGIS Implementation Specification for Geographic information
Simple feature access
Part 1: Common architecture
OpenGIS Implementation Specification for Geographic information — Simple feature access — Part 1: Common architecture
bibitem.abstract: The OpenGIS® Simple Features Interface Standard (SFS) provides a well-defined and common way for applications to store and access feature data in relational or object-relational databases, so that the data can be used to support other applications through a common feature model, data store and information access interface. OpenGIS Simple Features are geospatial features described using vector data elements such as points, lines and polygons.

bibitem.title: Geographic information — Well-known text representation of coordinate reference systems
Geographic information — Well-known text representation of coordinate reference systems
bibitem.abstract: This Standard defines the structure and content of well-known text strings describing coordinate reference systems (CRSs) and coordinate operations between coordinate reference systems. It does not prescribe how implementations should read or write these strings. This Standard provides an updated version of WKT representation of coordinate reference systems that follows the provisions of ISO 19111:2019. It extends the WKT in OGC document 12-063r5 (ISO 19162) which was based on ISO 19111:2007 and ISO 19111-2:2009. That version consolidated several disparate versions of earlier WKT (so-called WKT1) and added the description of coordinate operations. This jointly developed draft has been submitted by ISO TC211 for circulation as a Draft International Standard (DIS). This version incorporates comments made during the ISO TC211 New Work Item Proposal acceptance ballot.

bibitem.title: OGC API
Features
Part 1: Core
OGC API — Features — Part 1: Core
bibitem.abstract: OGC API standards define modular API building blocks to spatially enable Web APIs in a consistent way. The OpenAPI specification is used to define the API building blocks. The OGC API family of standards is organized by resource type. This standard specifies the fundamental API building blocks for interacting with features. The spatial data community uses the term ‘feature’ for things in the real world that are of interest.

bibitem.title: OGC API
Common
Part 1: Core
OGC API — Common — Part 1: Core
bibitem.abstract: The OGC has extended its suite of Standards to include Resource Oriented Architectures and Web APIs. In the course of developing these Standards, some practices proved to be common across multiple OGC Web API Standards. These common practices are documented in the OGC API — Common Standard. The OGC API - Common Standard is a multi-part standard that specifies reusable building-blocks that can be used in the construction of OGC API Standards. This document presents Part 1, the Core, of the OGC API – Common Standard. Standards developers will use these building-blocks in the construction of other OGC Standards that relate to Web APIs. The result is a modular suite of coherent API standards which can be adapted by a system designer for the unique requirements of their system. The purpose of the OGC API — Common — Part 1: Core Standard (API-Core) is to define those fundamental building blocks and requirements which are applicable to all OGC Web API Standards.
